Report of Independent Auditors
To the Administrator of Pension and Retirement Plan
Opinion
We have audited the accompanying financial statements of Pension and Retirement Plan (the "Plan"), an
employee benefit plan subject to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA), which
comprise the statements of net assets available for benefits as of December 31, 2024 and 2023, and the
related statements of changes in net assets available for benefits for the years then ended, including the
related notes (collectively referred to as the "financial statements").
In our opinion, the accompanying financial statements present fairly, in all material respects, the net assets
available for benefits of the Plan as of December 31, 2024 and 2023, and the changes in its net assets
available for benefits for the years then ended, in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted
in the United States of America.
Basis for Opinion
We conducted our audit in accordance with auditing standards generally accepted in the United States of
America (US GAAS). Our responsibilities under those standards are further described in the Auditors'
Responsibilities for the Audit of the Financial Statements section of our report. We are required to be
independent of the Plan and to meet our other ethical responsibilities, in accordance with the relevant
ethical requirements relating to our audit. We believe that the audit evidence we have obtained is sufficient
and appropriate to provide a basis for our audit opinion.
Responsibilities of Management for the Financial Statements
Management is responsible for the preparation and fair presentation of the financial statements in
accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America, and for the
design, implementation, and maintenance of internal control relevant to the preparation and fair
presentation of financial statements that are free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error.
In preparing the financial statements, management is required to evaluate whether there are conditions or
events, considered in the aggregate, that raise substantial doubt about the Plan's ability to continue as a
going concern for one year after the date the financial statements are available to be issued.
Management is also responsible for maintaining a current plan instrument, including all plan amendments,
administering the plan, and determining that the plan's transactions that are presented and disclosed in the
financial statements are in conformity with the plan's provisions, including maintaining sufficient records
with respect to each of the participants, to determine the benefits due or which may become due to such
participants.

Auditors’ Responsibilities for the Audit of the Financial Statements
Our objectives are to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements as a whole are free
from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error, and to issue an auditors' report that includes our
opinion. Reasonable assurance is a high level of assurance but is not absolute assurance and therefore is not
a guarantee that an audit conducted in accordance with US GAAS will always detect a material misstatement
when it exists. The risk of not detecting a material misstatement resulting from fraud is higher than for one
resulting from error, as fraud may involve collusion, forgery, intentional omissions, misrepresentations, or
the override of internal control. Misstatements are considered material if there is a substantial likelihood
that, individually or in the aggregate, they would influence the judgment made by a reasonable user based on
the financial statements.
In performing an audit in accordance with US GAAS, we:
• Exercise professional judgment and maintain professional skepticism throughout the audit.
• Identify and assess the risks of material misstatement of the financial statements, whether due to
fraud or error, and design and perform audit procedures responsive to those risks. Such procedures
include examining, on a test basis, evidence regarding the amounts and disclosures in the financial
statements.
• Obtain an understanding of internal control relevant to the audit in order to design audit procedures
that are appropriate in the circumstances, but not for the purpose of expressing an opinion on the
effectiveness of the Plan's internal control. Accordingly, no such opinion is expressed.
• Evaluate the appropriateness of accounting policies used and the reasonableness of significant
accounting estimates made by management, as well as evaluate the overall presentation of the
financial statements.
• Conclude whether, in our judgment, there are conditions or events, considered in the aggregate, that
raise substantial doubt about the Plan's ability to continue as a going concern for a reasonable period
of time.
We are required to communicate with those charged with governance regarding, among other matters, the
planned scope and timing of the audit, significant audit findings, and certain internal control-related matters
that we identified during the audit.

NOTE 1 - DESCRIPTION OF PLAN
The following description of the Pension and Retirement Plan (the "Plan") is provided for general purposes only. Participants
should refer to the Plan document and Summary Plan Description for a more complete description of the Plan's provisions.
General
The Plan is a noncontributory defined benefit plan which covers eligible employees of Corteva Agriscience, LLC (the
“Company” or “Corteva”), and its affiliated companies Pioneer Hi-Bred International, Inc. (“Pioneer”), PHI Financial Services,
Inc., and Corteva Agriscience Puerto Rico, Inc. Participants who were employed by ChemFirst Inc. (“ChemFirst”), Danisco A/
S ("Danisco"), Sentinel Transportation Company LLC ("Sentinel"), and Solae, LLC ("Solae") and have a vested benefit are also
covered by the Plan. ChemFirst, Danisco, Pioneer, Sentinel and Solae each have a different benefit section (Title) in the Plan
and their employees are covered by these separate pension benefit provisions.
EIDP, Inc. (formerly known as E. I. du Pont de Nemours and Company) (“DuPont” or “EIDP”) is the Plan Sponsor.
The Plan is subject to the provisions of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (“ERISA”).
In November 2016, DuPont announced that the Plan would freeze the pay and service amounts used to calculate pension
benefits for active employees who participate in the Plan on November 30, 2018 (“the Effective Date”). As of the Effective
Date, active employees in the Plan no longer accrue additional benefits for future benefit service and eligible compensation
received.
Administration
The Plan Administrator is the Benefit Plans Administrative Committee (the “Benefits Committee”), which is appointed by the
Company. The Benefits Committee may adopt, subject to the approval of the Company, such rules as it may deem necessary for
the proper administration of the Plan.
The assets of the Plan are held in the DuPont Pension Trust ("Master Trust"), of which 100% is owned by the Plan as of
December 31, 2024 and 2023. The Board of Directors of the Company, or its delegate, appoints a trustee to hold the assets of
the Master Trust in a trust. The trustee of the Master Trust is State Street Bank and Trust Company (“State Street” or the
“trustee”).
The management of the assets of the Master Trust are overseen by the Pension Investment Committee ("the Investment
Committee"), which is appointed by the Chief Executive Officer of Corteva, Inc. The assets of the Plan invested in the Master
Trust are managed by DuPont Capital Management Corporation (“DCMC”), a registered investment advisor and wholly-owned
subsidiary of Corteva, Inc. DCMC also determines the Master Trust's valuation policies. See Note 5 for additional information.
Plan Benefits
Participating employees become vested in the Plan after the completion of five years of service (three years for Danisco
employees) or the attainment of normal retirement age. Normal retirement age for ChemFirst, DuPont, and Pioneer participants
is the latter of age 65 or the age at which five years of service are completed. For all other sections of the Plan, the normal
retirement age is 65. Participants are eligible to receive vested benefits upon termination of employment, retirement, death or
total disability and the benefits may be paid immediately if age and service requirements are met. Benefits are determined using
a formula which takes into account service and final average earnings and are paid as a monthly annuity over the remaining
lifetime of the participant. ChemFirst, Danisco, and Sentinel employees may elect to receive the benefits as a lump sum
payment. Effective January 1, 2024, a former employee with a vested pension benefit having a total present value less than or
equal to $7,000 is cashed out of the Plan, representing an increase from the $5,000 limit previously in place. Required minimum
distributions will begin no later than April of the calendar year following the latter of the year in which the participant attains
the required minimum distribution age or the year following retirement or termination of employment. As a result of the
Consolidated Appropriations Act of 2023, which includes the Setting Every Community Up Retirement Enhancement
("SECURE") 2.0 Act, the required minimum distribution age is 70 ½ for anyone born before July 1, 1949, age 72 for anyone
born on or between July 1, 1949 and December 31, 1950, age 73 for anyone born on or between January 1, 1951 and December
31, 1959, and age 75 for anyone born on or after January 1, 1960.

In October 2023, the Plan purchased a group annuity contract from an insurance company for approximately 4,600 participants
who were receiving monthly pension benefits. Their last payments from the Plan were on either November 30, 2023 or
December 1, 2023. As a result of the annuity purchase amounting to $268,134, there was a corresponding decrease in the
present value of accumulated plan benefits of $297,564 (see Note 3). Subsequent to the last payment date, these individuals will
continue to receive monthly payments from the insurance company.
Death and Disability Benefits
If an active employee dies with a vested benefit, death benefits are payable to the surviving spouse or other eligible beneficiary.
Effective January 1, 2015, for participants who become totally disabled, no specific disability benefit is offered. For a disability
which occurred prior to January 1, 2015, disability benefits are payable in accordance with the plan provisions for their specific
section of the Plan (ChemFirst, Danisco, DuPont, Pioneer, Sentinel or Solae).
NOTE 2 - SIGNIFICANT ACCOUNTING POLICIES
Basis of Accounting
The accompanying financial statements of the Plan have been prepared on the accrual basis of accounting in accordance with
generally accepted accounting principles in the United States of America (“GAAP”).
Use of Estimates
The preparation of financial statements in conformity with GAAP requires management to make estimates and assumptions that
affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, and changes therein, disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities, and the
actuarial present value of accumulated plan benefits and changes therein at the date of the financial statements. Actual results
could differ from those estimates.
Risks and Uncertainties
The assets of the Plan are held in the Master Trust. The Master Trust invests in various investment securities. Investment
securities, in general, are exposed to various risks such as interest rate risk, credit risk, and overall market volatility. Market
risks include global events which could impact the value of investment securities, such as a pandemic, international conflict or
significant changes in trade, tax or other policies. Due to the level of risk associated with certain investment securities, it is at
least reasonably possible that changes in the values of investment securities will occur in the near term and that such changes
could materially affect the amounts reported in the Statements of Net Assets Available for Benefits.
Plan contributions are made and the actuarial present value of accumulated plan benefits are reported based on certain
assumptions pertaining to interest rates, inflation rates and employee demographics, all of which are subject to change. Due to
uncertainties inherent in the estimations and assumptions process, it is at least reasonably possible that changes in these
estimates and assumptions in the near term could be material to the financial statements.
Investment Valuation and Income Recognition
Investments are reported at fair value. Fair value is the price that would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability
in an orderly transaction between market participants at the measurement date. The fair value of the Plan's interest in the Master
Trust is based on the beginning of the year value of the Plan's interest in the Master Trust plus actual contributions and allocated
investment income and gains or losses, including the change in the value of investments, less actual distributions, and actual
and allocated administrative expenses. Net investment income or loss from the Master Trust is allocated proportionately on a
monthly basis based on the Plan's interest in the Master Trust. See Note 5 for additional information.
Payment of Benefits
Benefit payments to participants are recorded upon distribution.
Plan Expenses
In general, independent auditor and actuarial consultant fees, premiums to the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, and other
expenses of administering the Plan are paid from the assets of the Plan. Expenses, such as trustee fees and expenses related to
investment of Plan assets, are included in the net investment income allocated from the Master Trust.

NOTE 3 - ACCUMULATED PLAN BENEFITS
Accumulated plan benefits are those future periodic payments that are attributable under the Plan's provisions to the service
employees have rendered. Accumulated plan benefits include benefits expected to be paid to (a) retired or terminated
employees or their beneficiaries, (b) beneficiaries of employees who have died, and (c) present employees or their beneficiaries.
Accumulated plan benefits for active employees are based on their estimated average pensionable compensation during the
three years (five years for ChemFirst, Danisco, Pioneer, and Solae employees) ending on the Effective Date. As of
December 31, 2024 and 2023, benefits payable under all circumstances - retirement, death, disability and termination of
employment - are included in the actuarial present value of accumulated plan benefits, to the extent they are deemed attributable
to employee service and pay rendered to the Effective Date.
The actuarial present value of accumulated plan benefits is the amount that results from applying actuarial assumptions to adjust
accumulated plan benefits to reflect the time value of money (through discounts for interest) and the probability of payment (by
means of decrements such as for death, disability, withdrawal or retirement) between the valuation date and the expected dates
of payment.

The significant assumptions used in the valuations at December 31, 2024 and 2023 were:

expectation of asset return in the supporting trust.
• Life expectancy of participants: For measuring the 2024 and 2023 present value of accumulated plan benefits, the Plan
adopted the amounts-weighted aggregate healthy Pri-2012 mortality tables for healthy participants, disabled Pri-2012
mortality table for disabled participants and Pri-2012 contingent survivors mortality table for current and future
survivors. These rates were projected generationally from 2012 using Aon’s November 2024 U.S. Endemic version of
MP-2021 improvement scale for 2024 and Aon's January 2024 U.S. Endemic version of MP-2021 improvement scale
for 2023.
• Retirement age at December 31, 2024 and December 31, 2023: age 50-69 at 7-40%; age 70 at 100%.
• Actuarial cost method: The unit credit cost method.
The foregoing actuarial assumptions are based on the presumption that the Plan will continue. If the Plan were to terminate,
different actuarial assumptions and other factors might be applicable in determining the actuarial present value of accumulated
plan benefits.
Change in Actuarial Assumptions
Summary and impact of assumptions changes for the December 31, 2024 valuation
The increase in the discount rate from 4.5 percent to 6.0 percent reduced the present value of accumulated plan benefits as of
December 31, 2024 by $1,429,780. The mortality improvement scale was updated to use Aon’s November 2024 U.S. Endemic
version of MP-2021 improvement scales, which reflects near-term and long-term adjustments for the novel coronavirus disease
("COVID-19"). As a result, the present value of the accumulated plan benefits as of December 31, 2024 increased by $3,180.
There was no other change to demographic assumptions.
Summary and impact of assumptions changes for the December 31, 2023 valuation
The mortality improvement scale was updated to use Aon’s January 2024 U.S. Endemic version of MP-2021 improvement
scales, which reflects near-term and long-term adjustments for COVID-19. This resulted in a higher average rate of
improvement in mortality than the improvement rates used for the December 31, 2022 valuation. As a result, the present value
of the accumulated plan benefits as of December 31, 2023, increased by $2,334. Other modifications to demographic
assumptions resulted in the decrease of $4,430 to the present value of accumulated plan benefits for the year ended
December 31, 2023.

Plan Allocation of Master Trust
The assets, income from investments and net appreciation (depreciation) of the Master Trust are allocated monthly among the
participating plans based on cumulative actual contributions and payments under each plan as of each month-end.
Master Trust Practices and Policies
Investments of the Master Trust in common stocks, including exchange-traded funds, and options are valued at the closing
exchange price reported in the active market in which the security is traded. Investments in U.S. government and corporate
obligations and foreign bonds are valued at the evaluated bid price reported in the active market in which the security is traded.
Investments in foreign bonds, equities and currencies are translated into U.S. dollars at end-of-period exchange rates. Money
market and short-term investment funds are valued at net asset value. Futures contracts are valued at their quoted daily
settlement prices. Forward foreign exchange contracts are valued upon closing exchange rates from each respective foreign
market. Most investments in hedge funds, real estate funds, and private corporate equity and debt investments are valued based
on net asset value as a practical expedient to estimate fair value. See Note 6 for additional information. Certain investments in
real estate and private corporate equity and debt are valued based on inputs as discussed on pages 18 and 19 for 2024 and 2023,
respectively.
The change in net appreciation (depreciation) as recorded in the statement of changes in Master Trust net assets consists of both
realized gains and losses and the change in unrealized appreciation and depreciation on investments bought and sold as well as
held during the year.
Dividends are recorded on the ex-dividend date and interest income is accrued as earned. All security transactions are recorded
on a trade-date basis.
The Master Trust pledged cash and U.S. Treasury securities as collateral related to futures and certain asset-backed debt
securities valued at $64,372 and $88,393, at December 31, 2024 and 2023, respectively.

Derivatives Policy
The Master Trust enters into contractual arrangements (derivatives) in carrying out its investment strategy, principally to: (i)
hedge a portion of the Master Trust's portfolio to limit or minimize exposure to certain risks; (ii) gain an exposure to a market
more rapidly or less expensively than could be accomplished through the use of the cash markets; and (iii) increase investment
returns by reducing the cost of structuring the portfolio or by capturing value disparities between financial instruments.
The Master Trust may utilize derivative investment instruments such as:
• Equity futures;
• Interest rate futures;
• Options on futures;
• Over-the-counter (“OTC”) options; and
• Forward exchange contracts.
Select major financial institutions are used in derivatives transactions.
When engaging in OTC and forward exchange contracts, there is exposure to credit loss in the event of nonperformance by the
counterparties to these transactions. The Master Trust manages this exposure through credit approvals, limits, monitoring
procedures, and to the extent possible, by restricting the period over which unpaid balances are allowed to accumulate. The
Master Trust does not anticipate nonperformance by counterparties to these contracts, and no material loss would be expected
from any such nonperformance. Procedures are in place to regularly monitor and report market and counterparty credit risks
associated with these instruments.
The following is a summary of the significant accounting policies associated with the Master Trust's use of derivatives:
Futures - The Master Trust invests in futures contracts for the express purposes of managing portfolio duration, hedging interest
rates, facilitating trading, simulating a fully invested position in the underlying bonds or indices while maintaining a cash
balance for liquidity, or adding value when these instruments are favorably priced. The primary risks associated with the use of
futures contracts are imperfect correlation between changes in market values of investments held by the Master Trust and the
prices of futures contracts, and the possibility of an illiquid market.
The Master Trust may purchase and sell financial futures contracts, which are commitments to purchase or sell a financial
instrument at a future date for a specified price. Upon entering into a contract, the Master Trust deposits and maintains initial
margin collateral as may be required by the exchange on which the transaction is effected. During the period the futures
contracts are open, changes in the value of the contract are recognized on a periodic basis to reflect the market value of the
contract at the end of each day's trading. The Master Trust periodically receives from or pays to the broker an amount of cash
equal to the fluctuation in the value of the contract as required by the exchange. Such receipts or payments are known as
"variation margin" and are included in realized gains or losses. Variation margin is recorded as an asset or liability in the
statement of Master Trust net assets and as net appreciation (depreciation) in the statement of changes in Master Trust net
assets. Financial futures contracts are utilized by the Master Trust as an alternative to direct investment in the underlying
securities as the purchase or sale of futures contracts involves less cash outlay. Futures may also be used for hedging purposes.
In engaging in futures transactions, the Master Trust is subject to a number of risks. Successful hedging transactions depend on
the ability to predict timing of, and future direction of, price movements. If the prediction is incorrect, the Master Trust may
realize a loss. There is also a risk that the price of the futures contract may not correlate with the price of the underlying
portfolio security or index. In addition, there is a possibility that there may not be a secondary market for the contracts, or that
the counterparty to a contract may default on its obligation to perform. Counterparty risk is mitigated by periodic variation
margins and the fact that the Master Trust enters into futures contacts only through exchanges.

Forward Exchange Contracts - Forward exchange contracts are marked-to-market based upon forward exchange rates and the
difference between contract value and market value is recorded as an asset or liability in the statement of Master Trust net
assets. The change in value of these forward exchange contracts is included as unrealized gains or losses in the statement of
changes in Master Trust net assets. When the forward exchange contract is closed or effectively settled, the Master Trust
transfers the unrealized appreciation (depreciation) to a realized gain or loss equal to the change between the value of the
forward exchange contract when it was opened and the value at the time it was closed or offset.
Foreign Exchange Spot and Forward Contracts
Forward exchange contracts may be utilized to hedge all or a portion of the currency exposure that results from the Master
Trust's holdings of equity and fixed income securities denominated in foreign currencies. From January through March 2023,
the Master Trust hedged approximately 60% of the foreign currency exposure of the portfolio invested in mature equity foreign
markets, in accordance with the investment policy. After March 2023, the Master Trust did not hedge this exposure. In both
periods, it did not hedge its exposure when the stocks or bonds were denominated in the currency of an emerging market
country.

Interest Rate Futures
In carrying out its interest rate futures investment strategy, the Master Trust uses long futures contracts, short futures contracts,
and options on securities and futures. Long-term futures contracts are exchange traded instruments used to provide liquidity, to
obtain a desired portfolio structure, and to capture relative value differences. Short-term futures contracts are exchange traded
instruments used to provide direct exposure to movements in short-term interest rates.
Short interest rate futures contracts are utilized for a variety of purposes, including (i) executing tactical asset overlay strategies
and (ii) hedging against selected risks in certain segments of the fixed income portfolio.

NOTE 6 - FAIR VALUE MEASUREMENTS
Accounting Standards Codification ("ASC") 820, Fair Value Measurements and Disclosures, provides a framework for
measuring fair value. That framework provides a fair value hierarchy that prioritizes the inputs to valuation techniques used to
measure fair value as follows: Level 1, which refers to securities valued using unadjusted quoted prices from active markets for
identical assets; Level 2, which refers to securities not traded on an active market but for which observable market inputs are
readily available; and Level 3, which refers to securities valued based on significant unobservable inputs. Assets and liabilities
are classified in their entirety based on the lowest level of input that is significant to the fair value measurement.
Fair value calculations may not be indicative of net realizable value or reflective of future fair values. Furthermore, although the
Master Trust believes its valuation methods are appropriate and consistent with other market participants, the use of different
methodologies or assumptions to determine the fair value of certain financial instruments could result in a different fair value
measurement at the reporting date.

The availability of observable market data is monitored to assess the appropriate classification of financial instruments within
the fair value hierarchy. Changes in economic conditions or model-based valuation techniques may require the transfer of
financial instruments from one fair value level to another. In such instances, the transfer is reported at the end of the reporting
period.
The fair value of the real estate funds is estimated based on costs, the direct capitalization method or the discounted cash flow
method. The direct capitalization method involves dividing the net operating income by a market capitalization rate. The
discounted cash flow method involves estimating the investment fund values based on net operating income less periodic
capital expenditures and reversion value at the conclusion of the holding period.
For other investments, management estimates the values of the investments using current and projected financial conditions,
debt obligations, applicable financial ratios, liquidity and related financial ratios, projected operating results, current offers to
purchase the investment, market valuations of comparable companies and company specific developments including exit
strategies and realization opportunities. Refer to the below table for further information on the valuation methods and inputs

NOTE 7 - RELATED PARTY AND PARTY-IN-INTEREST TRANSACTIONS
The assets of the Plan invested in the Master Trust are managed by DCMC under the terms of an investment management
agreement between DCMC and the Plan Sponsor. Under this agreement, expenses associated with DCMC's investment
management activities can be recovered by the Plan Sponsor from the Master Trust. These expenses were $35,973 and $36,612
for the years ended December 31, 2024 and 2023, respectively. At December 31, 2024 and 2023, the Master Trust's unpaid
administrative expenses to DCMC amounted to $20,183 and $23,322, respectively.
At December 31, 2024 and 2023, the Master Trust held 2,311,058 and 4,260,223 shares of Corteva common stock, with a
market value of $131,638 and $204,150, respectively. In November 2024, the Master Trust sold 1,949,165 shares of Corteva
common stock to Corteva, Inc. for $125,000 as part of the Pension Investment Committee's periodic portfolio rebalancing
process.
The Master Trust invests in the State Street Institutional U.S. Government Money Market Fund at December 31, 2024 and
December 31, 2023.
These transactions qualify as party-in-interest transactions permitted under the provisions of ERISA.
NOTE 8 - COMMITMENTS
At December 31, 2024, the Master Trust, through investments in private corporate equity investments, debt investments and
real estate funds, is committed to make potential additional investments under capital calls approximating a maximum
$462,517. The issuance of capital calls depends upon the managers of the private investments identifying further investments
which they consider desirable for purchase. Additionally, the Master Trust is committed to the payment through capital calls of
management fees to the advisers of certain private investments.
In the normal course of business, the Master Trust enters into contracts with service providers that contain general
indemnification clauses. The Master Trust's maximum exposure under the arrangements is unknown as this would involve
future claims that may be made against the Master Trust that have not yet occurred. However, based on experience, the Master
Trust expects the risk of loss to be remote.

NOTE 9 - TAX STATUS
The IRS has determined and informed the Plan Administrator by the letter dated September 26, 2016, that the Plan is qualified
under the applicable sections of the Internal Revenue Code ("IRC"). The determination letter covers the Plan and amendments
through December 15, 2015. The Plan has been amended since receiving the determination letter. The Plan Administrator
believes that the Plan is designed and is currently being operated in accordance with the applicable requirements of the IRC.
Therefore, no provision has been made for federal income taxes in the Plan's financial statements.
GAAP requires Plan management to evaluate tax positions taken by the Plan and recognize a tax liability if the Plan has taken
an uncertain tax position that more likely than not would not be sustained upon examination by the IRS. The Plan Administrator
has analyzed the tax positions taken by the Plan and has concluded that as of December 31, 2024 and 2023, there are no
uncertain positions taken, or expected to be taken, that would require recognition of a liability or disclosure in the financial
statements. The Plan is subject to routine audits by taxing jurisdictions; however, there are currently no audits for any tax
periods in progress. The Plan Administrator believes the Plan is no longer subject to initiation of any new tax examinations for
years prior to 2019.
NOTE 10 - PLAN TERMINATION
Although it has not expressed any intention to do so, the Company reserves the right to terminate the Plan. In the event the Plan
is terminated, the net assets of the Plan shall be allocated, as prescribed by ERISA and its related regulations, generally to
provide the following benefits in the order indicated:
1. Benefits attributable to employee contributions, taking into account those paid out before termination.
2. Annuity benefits that former employees or their beneficiaries have been receiving for at least three years, or that
employees eligible to retire for that three-year period would have been receiving if they had retired with benefits in the
normal form of annuity under the Plan. The priority amount is limited to the lowest benefit that was payable (or would
have been payable) during those three years. The amount is further limited to the lowest benefit that would be payable
under Plan provisions in effect at any time during the five years preceding Plan termination.
3. Other vested benefits insured by the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation ("PBGC") (a U.S. government agency)
up to the applicable limitations.
4. All other vested benefits (that is, vested benefits not insured by the PBGC).
5. All nonvested benefits.
Certain benefits under the Plan are insured by the PBGC if the Plan terminates. Generally, the PBGC guarantees most vested
normal age retirement benefits, early retirement benefits, and certain disability and survivor's pensions. However, the PBGC
does not guarantee all types of benefits under the Plan, and the amount of benefit protection is subject to certain limitations.
Vested benefits under the Plan are guaranteed at the level in effect on the date of the Plan's termination.
Whether all participants receive their benefits should the Plan terminate at some future time will depend on the sufficiency, at
that time, of the Plan's net assets to provide for accumulated benefit obligations and may also depend on the financial condition
of the plan sponsor and the level of benefits guaranteed by the PBGC.

Schedule SB, Part V — Statement of Actuarial
Assumptions/Methods
Interest Rates for Minimum Funding Purposes Based on segment rates with a four-month lookback (as
of September 2023), each adjusted as needed to fall
within the 25-year average interest rate stabilization
corridor under ARPA.
1st Segment Rate 4.75%
2nd Segment Rate 4.87%
3rd Segment Rate 5.59%
Interest Rates for Maximum Tax Purposes Based on segment rates with a four-month lookback (as
of September 2023), without regard to interest rate
stabilization.
1st Segment Rate 3.62%
2nd Segment Rate 4.46%
3rd Segment Rate 4.52%
Decrement Timing Middle of year decrements, with 100% retirement
occurring at beginning of year.
Valuation of Plan Assets Smoothed fair market value of assets over the current
and prior two years, adjusted for contributions, benefit
payments, administrative expenses, and expected
earnings. The average value of assets calculated in this
manner is further limited to not less than 90% nor more
than 110% of fair market value.
A characteristic of this method is that the expected
distribution of the value of plan assets is skewed toward
understatement relative to the corresponding market
values for expected long-term rates of return in excess of
the third segment rate under IRC section 430(h)(2)(C)(iii).

Title VII (Solae)
Background The Solae Pension Plan (Plan) was formerly known as the
Protein Technologies International Retirement Plan. The
Protein Technologies International Retirement Plan was
adopted effective December 3, 1997, upon the
acquisition of Protein Technologies International (PTI) by
DuPont from Ralston Purina. Employees of PTI who had
service in the Ralston Purina Plan were credited with
service under the Protein Technologies International
Retirement Plan. Protein Technologies International later
became known as DuPont Protein Technologies.
Effective with the conversion of DuPont Protein
Technologies to Solae, LLC on April 1, 2003, the plan was
amended and renamed the Solae Pension Plan. Bunge
became a member of Solae, LLC and designated former
employees of Central Soya (which was owned by Bunge)
became participants in the plan on April 1, 2003. For the
former employees of Central Soya, service will be
credited in accordance with the terms of the plan.
Eligibility The Solae Pension Plan is available to all full-time and
part-time employees hired before January 1, 2013.
Temporary employees and leased employees are not
eligible. Each employee shall become a participant of the
plan after one year of service with the company.
The plan was closed on January 1, 2013. Rehires and
transfers after this date are not eligible for additional
benefits.
Benefit Sunset Date Benefit service and pensionable pay were frozen
effective November 30, 2018.
Credited Service An employee′s entire period of service (in years and
completed months) including service recognized under
the Ralston Purina Retirement Plan on December 3, 1997,
or the Central Soya Retirement Plan on April 1, 2003. It
does not include service recognized under the Central
Soya Pension Plan for Hourly Employees as of April 1,
2003.
Credited Service for Vesting The same as credited service but also includes service
recognized under the Central Soya Pension Plan for
Hourly Employees as of April 1, 2003.

Plan Changes Since January 1, 2019
The following plan changes have been adopted since January 1, 2019:
● A retiree annuity purchase was executed in September 2021, which included participants under Title I, III,
and IV with a monthly annuity of $400 or less and no contingent survivor benefits. The annuity payments
were taken over by an insurer in December 2021 or January 2022 depending on the payment timing of
each respective title. No future benefits are due to these participants from the Pension & Retirement Plan
effective with this annuity purchase.
● An annuity purchase was executed in August 2022, which included certain participants under Title I, III,
and IV. The annuity payments were taken over by an insurer in December 2022 or January 2023 depending
on the payment timing of each respective title. No future benefits are due to these participants from the
Pension & Retirement Plan effective with this annuity purchase.
● A retiree annuity purchase was executed in October 2023, which included certain participants under Title
I, III, and IV. The annuity payments were taken over by an insurer in December 2023 or January 2024
depending on the payment timing of each respective title. No future benefits are due to these participants
from the Pension & Retirement Plan effective with this annuity purchase.
Other Information to Fully and Fairly Disclose the Actuarial Position of
the Plan
Due to software limitations with the electronic filing process, information filed electronically cannot be
controlled by the Enrolled Actuary. The values on the signed Schedule SB will govern to the extent there are
any differences in the entries filed electronically and the actual data contained on the signed Schedule SB.
Under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (ARPA), the stabilized interest rates for certain purposes will
be adjusted once the ARPA stabilization is applied. By default, this stabilization would have applied starting
with the 2020 plan year. On November 15, 2021, Corteva made an election to:
● First apply the alternative interest rates for minimum funding for the 2021 plan year, and
● First apply the 15-year amortization period for the 2021 plan year.
As a result, this Schedule SB reflects stabilized 2024 minimum funding interest rates under ARPA.

Schedule SB, line 24 — Change in Actuarial Assumptions
The ERISA funding valuation reflects the following assumption changes:
● A change in the interest rate assumption from segment rates with a four-month lookback as of September
2022 to segment rates with a four-month lookback as of September 2023, each adjusted as needed to fall
within the 25-year interest rate stabilization corridor under ARPA.
● A change in the mortality assumption from the 2023 static mortality table for annuitants and
non-annuitants per §1.430(h)(3)-1(e) and IRS Notice 2020-85 to the 2024 generational mortality table for
annuitants and non-annuitants per §1.430(h)(3)-1(a)(3) and IRS Notice 2023-73.
● A change in the applicable expected rate of return on assets from 5.74% for the 2023 plan year to 5.59%
for the 2024 plan year.
These changes were made to better reflect the anticipated plan experience. All assumption changes to
non-prescribed assumptions did not reduce the funding shortfall by an amount requiring approval of the
Commissioner.

Eligibility Age 65 with at least 15 years of service.

16.67% of the Primary Social Security Benefit
multiplied by the ratio of service after
December 31, 2007 over total service.

December 31, 2007, plus 10% of Average Monthly
Pay at December 31, 2007.

Deferred Pension (Section VI)
Benefit Benefits are unreduced at age 65 and over. Benefits are
reduced by 5/12 of 1% for each month by which the
month of the participant’s retirement precedes the
earliest month in which, with continued employment, he
would have become eligible for an unreduced pension.
● Employees with less than 10 years of service are not
eligible for any benefit until age 65.
● Employees with 10 – 14 years of service are eligible
for reduced benefits at age 60 and unreduced
benefits at age 65.
● Employees with 15 – 29 years of service are eligible
for reduced benefits at age 50 and unreduced
benefits at age 65.
● Employees with 30+ years of service are eligible for
reduced benefits at age 50 and unreduced benefits
at age 60.

employee with at least 15 years of service upon death.

Pay at December 31, 2007 multiplied by years of
service through December 31, 2007.
(2) $4 per month multiplied by years of service through

Retirement, and spouse age differences (if spouse is at
least five years younger).

The ERISA funding valuation reflects the following assumption changes:
● A change in the interest rate assumption from segment rates with a four-month lookback as of September
2022 to segment rates with a four-month lookback as of September 2023, each adjusted as needed to fall
within the 25-year interest rate stabilization corridor under ARPA.
● A change in the mortality assumption from the 2023 static mortality table for annuitants and
non-annuitants per §1.430(h)(3)-1(e) and IRS Notice 2020-85 to the 2024 generational mortality table for
annuitants and non-annuitants per §1.430(h)(3)-1(a)(3) and IRS Notice 2023-73.
● A change in the applicable expected rate of return on assets from 5.74% for the 2023 plan year to 5.59%
for the 2024 plan year.

non-prescribed assumptions did not reduce the funding shortfall by an amount requiring approval of the
